question.title: Java Swing - How to convert insets to array?
question.body:
I'm trying to use JTable to make a 9x9 grid, and then use a BorderColorRenderer to set every 3rd column and row to have a thicker line (think sudoku board). I can easily get it working one way (i.e. only columns or only rows), which makes sense with my current code:

private static class BorderColorRenderer extends DefaultTableCellRenderer {
    public Component getTableCellRendererComponent(JTable table, Object value, boolean isSelected, boolean hasFocus, int row, int column) {
        Border border;
        JComponent comp = (JComponent)super.getTableCellRendererComponent(table, value, isSelected, hasFocus, row, column);
        
        if(column%3 == 0) {
            border = BorderFactory.createMatteBorder(0, 2, 0, 0, Color.BLACK);
        }else if(column==8){
            border = BorderFactory.createMatteBorder(0, 0, 0, 2, Color.BLACK);
        }else {
            border = BorderFactory.createMatteBorder(0, 0, 0, 0, Color.BLACK);
        }
        
        
        comp.setBorder(border);
        return comp;
    }
}

Obviously, it is "resetting" the borders each time, so when I add another if to the end to check rows it will reset the 0, 2, 0, 0 and make the 2 a 0 (so regular border).

My idea was to get the current border values, which I can do with getInsets(), and then use those values to add a 2 where I need it (when a column line and row line intersect/occur in the same cell of the table). However, getInsets() returns an Inset object, and I can't access any of the values in it nor covert to an array (as far as I have tried).

How can I go about doing this?

answers.body:
Disregarding the practicality of this approach, a quick look at the documentation for Insets quickly reveals that the 4 metrics (top, bottom, left, right) are just public int fields, you can modify them like so:

Insets insets = getInsets();
insets.left += 2;
insets.right += 2;
insets.top += 2;
insets.bottom += 2;

This is a bit of an old-ism as newer code tends to use getters (for a variety of sane reasons), but it's still just as valid. To "convert it to an array" as you have requested, you would need to decide on a packing order:

static int[] insetsToArray(Insets insets) {
     return new int[] { insets.left, insets.top, insets.right, insets.bottom };
}

Also consider that some method getInsets may be pure, in that it creates a new object instead of reporting a retained object. In that case, simply modifying the provided object is not sufficient to affect the provider's internal state, you would need to reapply it with the matching setter (look for setInsets).

Obviously, it is "resetting" the borders each time...

So you need to use compound if statements to check the row and column when borders overlap. These statements should be the first statements in your if/else logic.

Simple example to get you started:

private static class BorderColorRenderer extends DefaultTableCellRenderer {
    public Component getTableCellRendererComponent(JTable table, Object value, boolean isSelected, boolean hasFocus, int row, int column) {
        Border border;
        JComponent comp = (JComponent)super.getTableCellRendererComponent(table, value, isSelected, hasFocus, row, column);

        if(column == 8 && row % 3 == 0) {
            border = BorderFactory.createMatteBorder(2, 0, 0, 2, Color.BLACK);
        }else if(column % 3 == 0 && row % 3 == 0) {
            border = BorderFactory.createMatteBorder(2, 2, 0, 0, Color.BLACK);
        }else if(column%3 == 0) {
            border = BorderFactory.createMatteBorder(0, 2, 0, 0, Color.BLACK);
        }else if(row%3 == 0) {
            border = BorderFactory.createMatteBorder(2, 0, 0, 0, Color.BLACK);
        }else if(column==8){
            border = BorderFactory.createMatteBorder(0, 0, 0, 2, Color.BLACK);
        }else {
            border = BorderFactory.createMatteBorder(0, 0, 0, 0, Color.BLACK);
        }

        comp.setBorder(border);
        return comp;
    }
}

question_comments.body: You want a graphical representation. That involves drawing of lines (grid) and other shapes (letters, symbols). At some point in the future, you will want to do even a bit more graphical stuff in that game, like line thickness/strikethrough, coloring, mouse-over or fade effects. Using a JTable - as your question proves - is way more complicated (looking at even only the basic components of a Sudoku game), than just using a JPanel where you override its paintChildren(Graphics g) method and do the whole painting thing in there. Call repaint() to have Swing invoke the paintX()methods.

I have no clue what you're even suggesting here, genuinely. What does my post have to do with sprites or transparency or frame rates? I'm literally just making a 9x9 grid using JTable and want to group together 3x3 grids with thicker lines to make a Sudoku board. Window sizes and aspect ratios are also completely irrelevant? Its a simple java  swing application, and I'm giving it a fixed size. Its just a fun little project for me, so other window sizes or aspect ratios don't matter at all.

This seems to be a completely convoluted approach. Why would you do such complicated messy stuff, when you simply can override the paint()/paintX()methods and use the Graphics/Graphics2D? That would easily enable you to do a lot more cool stuff with interpolation, transparencies, gradients, frame rates, transposing, scaling, sprites. All without messing with TableCellRenderers and TableModels etc, that were never designed for this... Not even speaking of scaling to different window sizes or aspect ratios.
